review.title: An empirical study for Vietnamese dependency parsing
review.abstract: This paper presents an empirical comparison of different dependency parsers for Vietnamese, which has some unusual characteristics such as copula drop and verb serialization. Experimental results show that the neural network-based parsers perform significantly better than the traditional parsers. We report the highest parsing scores published to date for Vietnamese with the labeled attachment score (LAS) at 73.53% and the unlabeled attachment score (UAS) at 80.66%.
histories: To appear in Proceedings of the 14th Annual Workshop of the Australasian Language Technology Association
review.COMMENTS: To appear in Proceedings of the 14th Annual Workshop of the Australasian Language Technology Association

metadata.title: An empirical study for Vietnamese dependency parsing∗

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Over the past decade, dependency parsing has become a central research topic in the processing of natural language, reinforced by the success of CoNLL 2006 and 2007, which shared tasks in the field of multilingual dependency parsing (Buchholz and Marsi, 2006; Nivre et al., 2007a). McDonald and Nivre (2011) identify two types of approaches to dependency parsing: graph-based approaches (McDonald et al., 2005) and transition-based approaches (Nivre et al., 2005; Nivre et al., 2007b; Bohnet et al.; Zhang and Nivre, 2011; Martins et al., 2013; Choi and McCallum, 2013) manually define a set of core and combined features associated with unilateral representations. Recent work shows that neural network-based parsers are the state-of-the-art parsing across many languages.

sections.heading: 2 Experimental setup
sections.text: Dataset: There are two Vietnamese dependency tree banks that are automatically converted from the manually annotated Vietnamese constitutional texts of 1997, using conversion approaches proposed by Thi et al. (2013) and Nguyen et al. (2014b). In Thi et al. (2013), it is not clear how the conversion approaches are derived; furthermore, it ignores grammatical information encoded in grammatical function labels. Furthermore, the approach of Thi et al. (2013) is unable to deal with cases of coordination and empty category mappings that frequently crop up in the Vietnamese constitution exemplary tree bank. Nguyen et al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al. (2014b), a new conversion approach is later proposed to deal with these cases.

sections.heading: 3 Main results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Overall accuracy
sections.text: Table 2 compares the parser results obtained from the four parsers. The first four lines indicate the values with Gold Part-of-Speech (POS) tags, while the last four lines represent the values with automatically predicted POS tags. 5As expected, the neural network-based parsers BistG and BistT perform significantly better than the traditional parsers MST and Malt.6 Specifically, we find 2 +% absolute improvements in the values of LAS and UAS for both graphical and transition- based types. sections.heading: 3.2 Accuracy analysis
sections.text: It is not surprising that most people who are able are able to play by the rules.

sections.heading: 3.3 Discussions
sections.text: Linguistic aspects: A surprising characteristic of the results is the poor performance of the verbrelated dependencies: vmod accuracy is low, as are the values associated with the second most common POS day V (verb). For the latter, we find significantly lower values for verbs in Vietnamese (about 65%, as shown in Table 4) compared to the values for verbs (about 80 +%) reported by MST andMalt Parser in 13 other languages reported in McDonald and Nivre (2011), and also much worse values in terms of ranks compared to other POS. This could be related to syntactic properties of Vietnamese (Thompson, 1987). Firstly, Vietnamese is described as a copula drop language. Consider Côhà có Hà a beautiful house, "in which the attributive adjective is called" beautiful, "which is" beautiful, "postmodifies the noun nacial" house "as an adjective" where they can also be predictive (where four).

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: Experimental results of the Vietnamese Dependency Treebank VnDT (Nguyen et al., 2014b) show that the neural network-based parsers (Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016b) achieve significantly higher values than the traditional parsers (McDonald et al., 2005; Nivre et al., 2007b). Specifically, we find an absolute improvement of 2% in the neural network-based parser for each graph or transition-based type compared to the traditional parser. We report the highest performance to date for the Vietnamese department, which parses with LAS at 73.53% and the United Arab Emirates at 80.66%.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The first author is supported by an International Postgraduate Research Scholarship and a NICTA NRPA Top-Up Scholarship.

metadata.abstractText: This paper presents an empirical comparison of different dependency parsers for Vietnamese, which has some unusual characteristics such as copula drop and verb serialization. Experimental results show that the neural network-based parsers perform significantly better than the traditional parsers. We report the highest parsing scores published to date for Vietnamese with the labeled attachment score (LAS) at 73.53% and the unlabeled attachment score (UAS) at 80.66%.
